snippet.textDisplay: When I think about aging, I think about sexual reproduction, generations, and selective pressures. It’s life’s grand form or renewal and change.  I don’t know if Moon jellies are the exception or rule amongst the jellies, but it seems like they might pay an evolutionary price for luxury of immortality.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's almost as if there is a reason why philosophies that insisted on practices he suggested exist.
Nowadays we are rediscovering this wisdom but are explaining it in a scientific way. And others would call it superstition or something degrading. There are reasons why the many ancient traditions were in existence in the first place.
It's like we became dumbed down so much that we need a scientist to figure things out for us instead of relying on wisdom.

snippet.textDisplay:
You answered HOW we're aging but not WHY we're aging.

Aging and dying is a part of the evolution process. By removing the aging process, we screw up evolution.

On the last excinction, it was the little rodent mammals that survived and adapt to the new environment and they certainly didn't have a lifespan of hundred years...

If all cells of any lifeforms in this world have longevity genes BUT the evolution selected the fact of only enabling it when facing adversity as optimal, maybe is it in fact..... optimal.... Maybe we shouldn't permantly enable it.

The "gorgeous" moon gellyfish is still.... a gellyfish...

And we're not rodent mammals anymore...
snippet.textOriginal:
You answered HOW we're aging but not WHY we're aging.

If all cells of any lifeforms in this world have longevity genes BUT the evolution selected the fact of only enabling it when facing adversity as optimal, maybe is it in fact..... optimal.... Maybe we shouldn't permantly enable it.

snippet.textDisplay: i can see a future where instead of people growing up and having kids  they wait on a waiting list like they do for organ donations today.  You literally have to wait for someone to have an accident.  That's not a bad thing and it would work for society quite well... at the moment ageing is a real drain on society.. and its getting worse.. people need care... they need looking after... my gran is 93... can't walk.. lives in a care home and is not happy about it. She's in and out of hospital etc etc... and the number like her is only set to increase... so finding a way to live longer youthfully and only allow reproduction when someone dies naturally without ageing seems great.  Of course, people will stay young... so will be able to have children much later in life.  Then think of the knowledge and skill of someone who has been doing their profession for 100 years and biologically is 30... they're sharp and youthful like a young person... but they're highly experienced and proficient like an old worker.
snippet.textOriginal: i can see a future where instead of people growing up and having kids  they wait on a waiting list like they do for organ donations today. snippet.textDisplay:
So I should stop eating Mc.Donalds every day, and I should be good to go then? x'D
I work at UPS. Loading packages into trailers. They get so cold during the winter that our water bottles freeze. Then so hot during the summer, that someone could pass out / get sick from overheating.
We're moving dozen pound boxes every dozen seconds. Between 1 and 150lbs. And walking / speed walking all shift long.

snippet.textDisplay: Very interesting stuff!  One thing I was wondering is if we can "program" a bacteria or virus to produce what is required to reverse aging.  Is aging treatable in the same way we use insulin to treat diabetes?  Although, I do see a problem with this resulting in more people populating the planet.  Perhaps, the individuals who wish to go through a "reset" have to go through voluntary sterilization.  In other words, you go through your life, have children if you wish, raise them, age, then have yourself sterilized, and finally resetting your age to... say 25?  That would keep our world population stable.
snippet.textOriginal: Very interesting stuff!  One thing I was wondering is if we can "program" a bacteria or virus to produce what is required to reverse aging.  Is aging treatable in the same way we use insulin to treat diabetes?  Although, I do see a problem with this resulting in more people populating the planet.  Perhaps, the individuals who wish to go through a "reset" have to go through voluntary sterilization.  In other words, you go through your life, have children if you wish, raise them, age, then have yourself sterilized, and finally resetting your age to... say 25?  That would keep our world population stable.

I feel pretty confident in that food and our environment are what give us a lot of the diseases and health complications that are said to come with age.
I keep thinking about the few people that have reversed HIV detection I'm by simply adopting a plant-based food lifestyle & good ol' exercise. Not to mention cancer remission....
However, if even raw fruits and vegetables are controlled, MANIPULATED/MUTATED and patented then that concerns me.

snippet.textDisplay:
All of these futuristic technologies coming around people seem to estimate the 2030-2060 range.
As someone born since the year 2000 I have to consider that I'll live well beyond that (presumably).
So I have to wonder, what kind of things will come after this range? Up to 2100 possibly, especially if the tech in this video comes to fruition on a similar timescale, and will only continue to get better after it does.
The future is confusing, and I love it.

snippet.textDisplay:
a point often discussed in fiction is what happens to how people are psychologically in response to having a longer life span. I think that potentially some positive emerge; older people (the fit and healthy ones) are usually wiser, less likely to be consumer junkies, less likely to be violent (even if strong) and less likely to see war as a good idea.

So controlling ageing and longevity while bringing health and vitality may indeed be a good thing. I think the fiction "Altered Carbon" discusses these points well (as well as many of the classic SF authors who handle this topic too).
snippet.textOriginal:

So controlling ageing and longevity while bringing health and vitality may indeed be a good thing. I think the fiction "Altered Carbon" discusses these points well (as well as many of the classic SF authors who handle this topic too).

snippet.textDisplay:
Does this professor has other scientists backing his claims ? Do we have solid data and evidence ? Where is the research at besides his own ? Don't get me wrong I already follow what he advices, and I would be hyper-hyped if it was true for aging. However whenever something that amazing is announced I think we should be super-prudent and doubtful, what seems to lack in this video (and also in its comments section), to my opinion.
Also I don't understand that all the advice seems to be life constraints that people from under-developped countries are forced to follow, but I don't have the impression that it makes them a big lifespan, (besides from the averaging effect coming from high infantile mortality rates). How do you explain that ?
snippet.textOriginal:

How do you explain that ?

snippet.textDisplay: The answer is in the introduction of your video. Can we extend the lifespan ? No we can't. Overpopulation issues would lead to a collapse of the current civilization, and you can't live longer in a collapsed world. You'd actually die younger, if you even happen to live.
snippet.textOriginal: The answer is in the introduction of your video. Can we extend the lifespan ? No we can't. Overpopulation issues would lead to a collapse of the current civilization, and you can't live longer in a collapsed world. You'd actually die younger, if you even happen to live.

snippet.textDisplay:
There are two problems with slowing aging:
1- Overpopulation : the longer we live, the longer we populate the limited in resources Earth. If we live twice longer, we have twice as many generations living together, so we double the population and double the environmental destruction.
2 - retirement plans: more older people, fewer young working people. That mathematically can't work. Look at what's happening currently in France with massive strikes lasting already 2 weeks, against a reform that aims to push the retirement age at 64.
snippet.textOriginal:
There are two problems with slowing aging:
1- Overpopulation : the longer we live, the longer we populate the limited in resources Earth. If we live twice longer, we have twice as many generations living together, so we double the population and double the environmental destruction. 
2 - retirement plans: more older people, fewer young working people. That mathematically can't work. Look at what's happening currently in France with massive strikes lasting already 2 weeks, against a reform that aims to push the retirement age at 64.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is not new information. There is a book that was written over a century and a half ago that highlighted these key principles. A group of people followed these principles which allowed their cluster to be identified as one of the Blue Zones. This particular zone was in California. If you would like to read the book, you can do so for free online.

And in response to your challenge in the comment section, I had the professor marked at 52 years of age. I am used to seeing people who follow these longevity principles, and actually find it shocking when I see young people look aged. The fast paced, processes food, easy drug access, electrical appliance filled lives that we live have been aging us prematurely.
snippet.textOriginal:
This is not new information.  There is a book that was written over a century and a half ago that highlighted these key principles.  A group of people followed these principles which allowed their cluster to be identified as one of the Blue Zones.  This particular zone was in California.  If you would like to read the book, you can do so for free online.  

And in response to your challenge in the comment section, I had the professor marked at 52 years of age.  I am used to seeing people who follow these longevity principles, and actually find it shocking when I see young people look aged.  The fast paced, processes food, easy drug access, electrical appliance filled lives that we live have been aging us prematurely.
